newsitem.title: TURKEY: New Turkish coalition paints glum economic picture.
newsitem.headline: New Turkish coalition paints glum economic picture.

text.p: Turkey's new secularist government painted on Wednesday a gloomier than expected picture of the economy inherited from the former Islamist-led coalition and shied away from making bold economic promises.

The economy and finance ministers reinforced fears about chronic inflation and gaping deficits, injecting a dose of realism into the economic picture after months of political chaos which helped them to power last week.

"Our aim is not to take shock decisions in the economy, but to sort out this business with fine tuning," State Minister Gunes Taner told a news conference to announce the economic plans of the left-right coalition.
"We do not have a magic wand in our hands, but we have knowledge and experience," said Taner, a member of the conservative and pro-market Motherland Party of Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz.

Leftist Finance Minister Zekeriya Temizel, who jointly gave the news conference with Taner, said the 1997 budget deficit was expected to leap to 2,400 trillion lira ($15.9 billion) from 1,218 trillion a year earlier.
Islamist former prime minister Necmettin Erbakan had programmed a balanced budget for 1997, but Temizel reiterated that figures for the first half of the year showed a deficit of 720 trillion lira.
Budget revenues in the full year were expected to amount to 5,112 trillion lira and expenditure was likely to total 7,510 trillion, he said.
Taner, who is responsible for the economy, said the anticipated deficit made it necessary to plan a supplementary budget in the region of 2,500 trillion lira.
The new government also tore up the inflation targets of the outgoing Islamist-led coalition, which collapsed last month under pressure from the secularist establishment.

The finance ministry revised the end-1997 inflation target up to 80-85 percent from a previous target of 57.7 percent, new figures released on Wednesday showed. The average rate for 1997 was forecast to reach 75-80 percent.
Economic growth appeared to be stronger than previously anticipated.
The target for gross national product growth in 1997 was lifted to 5.5-6.0 percent from four percent previously.
Taner said he was opposed to Turkey reaching a stand-by accord with the International Monetary Fund. IMF officials visited Turkey earlier this year, but there was no agreement on such an accord.
"There is no need for such an agreement. But we are members of the IMF and we will certainly hold talks," he said in answer to a question.
He also repeated a previous government pledge to refrain from intervention in interest rates and the currency markets and tighten up tax collection.
The government target for privatisation revenues in 1997 stood at $4 billion.
An ambitious sell-off timetable was a cornerstone of Erbakan's bold economic plans, who promised tens of billions of dollars in fresh revenues but failed to deliver during his one year in office.
Finance Minister Temizel said domestic debt at the end of June stood at 4,213 trillion lira, while foreign debt totalled $80 billion.
Among other finance ministry targets, 1997 exports were revised to $25.5-26 billion from $29.5 billion and the import target was revised to $45.5-46 billion from $50 billion.

The current account deficit was targeted to reach $4-4.5 billion in 1997, compared with an earlier target of $5.6 billion. The Turkish lira was expected to reach an average rate for 1997 of 147,000-150,000 against the dollar.
($1 = 150,900 Turkish lira)
